Every year update age book confronted mortality getting ever closer.today stores result function Sys.Date(). function returns computer system's date. heading: 2.3 Activity 1: The Stroop Effect
text: chapter next chapter, going develop data skills using data one famous experiments psychology: Stroop Effect.First, taken part online version Stroop test. takes minutes complete. need device keyboard.Second, read Wikipedia summary Stroop Effect used psychological research.Finally, answer following questions. Please note responses save browser - want save , make note somewhere.Stroop Effect primarily measure?Color perceptionLanguage comprehensionCognitive interferenceReading speedThe Stroop Effect primarily measures cognitive interference, occurs processing specific stimulus feature impedes simultaneous processing second stimulus attribute.one possible explanation Stroop Effect?People naturally slower reading identifying colorsReading automatic process can interfere color identificationColor identification automatic process can interfere readingNone aboveThe Stroop Effect often explained theory automaticity, suggests reading—task recognizing words—become automatic process individuals, automatic reading process interferes task naming color.typical Stroop test,  trials (color ink matches word) completed faster  trials (color ink match word).Answer: congruent, incongruentIn typical Stroop test, two types tasks - congruent incongruent.Congruent tasks color ink matches word. example, word "BLUE" printed blue ink. case, visual color semantic information (meaning word) align "congruent."Incongruent tasks, hand, color ink match word. example, word "BLUE" might printed red ink. , visual color semantic information conflict "incongruent."Participants Stroop test typically asked name color ink, word. interference comes . Reading words automatic process literate adults participant's brain automatically reads word recognizing color ink. causes delay response time incongruent tasks, brain overcome initial automatic response read word.Therefore, congruent tasks typically completed faster incongruent tasks Stroop test. difference response times measure Stroop effect, demonstrates nature cognitive interference automatic process reading.

heading: 2.8.2 Function Help
text: want information function use , can look help document. function base R package loaded, can type ?function_name console access help file. top help give function package name.package loaded, use ?package_name::function_name. sure package function , use shortcut ??function_name give list possible options.console, type run code different help options . reason run help code console code chunk generally want save code script.Function help always organised way. example, look help ?beepr::beep. top, tells name function package curly brackets, short description function, followed longer description. Usage section shows function arguments. arguments default values, shown like function(arg = default). Arguments section lists argument explanation. may Details section even detail functions. Examples section last, shows examples can run console window see function works.Use help documentation find answers questions:first argument mean function? trimna.rmmeanxWhat package read_excel ? readrreadxlbasestats
code:
# get help with a package
?beepr

# get help with a function if the package it's from is already loaded
?beep

# get help with a function whether or not the package is loaded
?beepr::beep

# shows a list of potentially matching functions
??beep

heading: 2.9.2 Read in the data {sec-read_csv}
text: Now can read data. use function read_csv() allows us read .csv files, type data file. also functions allow read .xlsx (Excel) files formats, however course use .csv files.First, create object called dat contains data experiment_data.csv file. , create object called ppt_info contains data participant_data.csv.code chunk 4, write run code load data files.order load file successfully, name file needs double quotation marks must file extension .csv. miss , get error message ...exist current working directory. fix , make sure spelled name file right included file extension.Additionally, get message find function "read_csv()" means loaded tidyverse - common error write code run ! fix , run code loads tidyverse. Another reason might see message made typo name function, check spelled read_csv exactly right.

ppt_info <- read_csv(file = "participant_data.csv")

Whenever read data R always initial check see data looks like expected. several ways can , try see results differ.environment pane, click dat ppt_info. open data give spreadsheet-like view (although edit like Excel).environment pane, click small blue play button left dat ppt_info. show structure object information including names variables object type .code chunk 5, write run summary(ppt_info) (dat)code chunk 5, write run str(ppt_info) (dat)mean age pf participants 1 decimal place? mean overall reaction time 1 decimal place?

heading: 2.11 Activity 7: Visualise the data
text:
going learn course, data visualisation extremely important. Visualisations can used give information dataset, can also used mislead.going look write code produce simple visualisations weeks, now, want focus read interpret different kinds graphs. Please feel free play around code change TRUE FALSE adjust values labels see happens worry understanding code now. Just copy paste .Copy, paste run code code chunk 6 produce bar graph shows number men, women, non-binary participants dataset.
Figure 2.2: Number participants gender
men, women, non-binary participants sample? menMore womenMore non-binary participantsCopy, paste, run code code chunk 7 create violin-boxplots happiness scores income group.
Figure 2.3: Violin-boxplot reaction times condition
violin (wavy line) shows density. Basically, fatter wavy shape, data points point. called violin plot often looks (kinda) like violin.boxplot box middle. black line shows median score group. median calculated arranging scores order smallest largest selecting middle score.lines boxplot show interquartile range. really good explanation read boxplot .condition longest median reaction time? CongruentIncongruent
code:
ggplot(ppt_info, # data we're using
       aes(x = gender, # variable we want to show as bars
                     fill = gender)) + # make bars different colours
  geom_bar(show.legend = FALSE) + # add bar plot & turn off redundant legend
  scale_x_discrete(name = "Gender") + # edit x-axis label
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "D") + # colour-blind friendly
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Number of participants")+ # edit y-axis label
  theme_minimal() # add a theme
# make plot
ggplot(dat, # data we're using
       aes(x = condition, # grouping variable (IV)
                     y = reaction_time, # measurement (DV)
                     fill = condition)) + # make bars different colours
  geom_violin(show.legend = FALSE, # turn off redundant legend for colour
              alpha = .4) + # make violin a bit transparent
  geom_boxplot(width = .2, # adjust size of boxplot
               show.legend = FALSE, # turn off redundant legend for colour
               alpha = .7)+ # make boxplots a little transparent
  scale_x_discrete(name = "Condition", # edit x-axis labels
                   labels = c("Congruent", "Incongruent")) +
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Reaction time (ms)") + # edit y-axis labels
  theme_minimal() + # add a theme
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "E") # colour-blind friendly colours

Remember avoid issues, always want start R new session clean environment make sure quit end chapter also check got settings right described Chapter 1.7.Refresh memory, thinking back know Stroop Effect, complete hypothesis using word "higher" "lower".H1: Reaction times congruent condition significantly  reaction times incongruent condition.H0: significant difference reaction times congruent incongruent condition.H1 DirectionalNon-directional hypothesis.context Stroop effect, generally expected reaction times faster (.e., lower) congruent condition incongruent condition. , congruent condition, color word match (e.g., word "RED" displayed red color), require additional cognitive processing resolve conflict. contrast, incongruent condition, color word different (e.g., word "RED" displayed blue color), creates cognitive conflict takes additional time resolve.hypothesis considered directional (one-tailed) predicts direction difference relationship. case, H1 predicts reaction times lower congruent condition incongruent condition, directional hypothesis. non-directional (two-tailed) hypothesis, hand, state difference reaction times two conditions, without specifying one expected faster.

heading: 3.5 Activity 3: Participant information
text: start simple analysis dataset first step, get descriptive information sample. already know 270 participants dataset, can check using code function count() comes dplyr package loaded part tidyverse.

heading: 3.5.1 Counting observations
text:
count() simply counts number observations (rows) object give . First, count number observations total dataset. important use ppt_info dataset wide-form 1 row = 1 participant. used dat, might think double number participants really .
* weird %>% symbol known pipe. formal definition pipe takes object sends next function maybe easier read . code reads "Take object ppt_infO count .can also use count() count number observations group. writing psychological research, common report gender split sample. , add gender count() function count number observations separately group variable gender:
code:
ppt_info %>%
  count()
ppt_info %>%
  count(gender)

heading: 3.5.2 Calculating summary statistics
text: also common report mean standard deviation age sample. Rather using count(), use function summarise() can used create summary statistics (e.g., mean, median, SD etc).summarise() create table summary statistics requested.bit left = sign name column create table, can call whatever want make informative easy read. Variable names spaces common separate words _ underscore. case, name column mean_age.bit right = sign calculation R perform. case, use function mean() variable age.can add multiple operations single call summarise(), example, can add calculation standard deviation:R, many functions calculate summary statistics. list commonly used functions:mean(x): Calculates arithmetic mean numeric vector x.median(x): Finds median x.max(x): Finds maximum value x.min(x): Finds minimum value x.range(x): Returns column containing minimum maximum given arguments.sum(x): Calculates sum values x.sd(x): Calculates standard deviation x.var(x): Computes variance x.n() Computes number observations, similar count()Add code also calculate median age participants store column named median_age.
code:
ppt_info %>%
  summarise(mean_age = mean(age))
ppt_info %>%
  summarise(mean_age = mean(age),
            sd_age = sd(age))
ppt_info %>%
  summarise(mean_age = mean(age),
            sd_age = sd(age),
            median_age = median(age))

heading: 3.5.3 Summarising by groups
text: Finally, can also compute summary statistics groups, just like count(). need take slightly different approach use additional function group_by(). group_by() group dataset whatever dataset next done separately group, example, group gender ask calculate mean age, calculate mean age separately gender.useful addition calculating summary statistics groups add call n(). function counts number observations group. gives info got used count() adding table useful reminder many data points used calculation. example, calculated mean score two groups one group 1000 participants 5 participants, good reminded different sizes.code chunk 2, add code calculate summary stats age group.gender highest mean age? MenNon-binaryWomenWhich gender highest median age? MenNon-binaryWomen
code:
ppt_info %>%
  group_by(gender) %>%
  summarise(mean_age = mean(age),
            sd_age = sd(age),
            median_age = median(age),
            group_size = n())

heading: 3.7 Activity 5: Data visualisation
text:
finish , make plots visualise data. , worry much understanding code right now, explain next set chapters. now, read code see can match code displays plot, try changing values TRUE FALSE see happens answer questions.code chunk 4, add code create boxplot reaction times condition.outliers congruent incongruent condition? congruentincongruentOn boxplot, outliers represented black dots beyond end whiskers. one outlier congruent condition, four incongruent condition.ggplot2 boxplot, outlier typically defined observation falls Q1 - 1.5IQR Q3 + 1.5IQR.Q1: first quartile, 25th percentile.
Q3: third quartile, 75th percentile.
IQR: stands Interquartile Range, calculated Q3 - Q1. IQR measure statistical dispersion, represents middle 50% data., boxplot, "box" represents IQR line inside box median (Q2). "whiskers" typically extend smallest largest observations within Q1 - 1.5IQR Q3 + 1.5IQR, respectively. observations fall outside range considered outliers usually represented points beyond whiskers.code chunk 5, add code create grouped histogram shows distribution reaction times different colour condition. can change colours like - use list colour names can use ggplot().frequent value reaction times congruent condition 800 ms1000 msA histogram shows distribution responses. x-axis value measurement, case reaction time milliseconds, y-axis count, .e., many times value occurs. frequent value therefore highest bar congruent condition around 800ms.code chunk 6, add code create grouped density plot another way visualising distribution variable?plot better representation distribution? HistogramDensity plotThey strengthsHistograms density plots graphical representations show distribution dataset, display data slightly different ways strengths.Histograms show distribution variable dividing data bins (represented bar), plotting number observations fall bin (frequency). height bar corresponds count data points within bin. Histograms useful want get sense count (frequency) distribution data, especially data points fall terms discrete bins.Density plots (also known Kernel Density Plots) show distribution variable estimating smooth "curve" (density function) fits distribution. Density plots can thought smoothed versions histograms: use kernel function create smooth curve, area curve represents total proportion observations. useful want visualize shape data distribution, can especially helpful identifying multiple modes (peaks) data.choice histograms density plots often comes specifics dataset want emphasize:interested exact distribution frequencies across bins, histogram might best choice.
interested overall shape data distribution, density plot might appropriate.
code:
ggplot(dat, aes(x = condition, y = reaction_time)) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .4)
ggplot(dat, aes(x = reaction_time, fill = condition)) +
  geom_histogram(colour = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("deepskyblue", "gold"))## `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
ggplot(dat, aes(x = reaction_time, fill = condition)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .4) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("deepskyblue", "gold"))
